"I front an organization that kills 1,200 people a day," says Nick Taylor (Aaron Eckhart), a lobbyist for the tobacco industry. His job is to stand up for tobacco companies that are being attacked by knuckleheads who accuse the businesses of being murdering bastards. Talyor loves what he does, and he's very good at it. He is able to attack his opponents from every angle imaginable. But as clever as he is, he never observes the fact that smoking is essentially long term suicide, and that some people who do smoke are too dumb to make an attempt to quit.

As a conservative Republican, I think that the attack on the tobacco industry is just as ridiculous as the attacks on gun manufacturers and McDonald's. Some may remember the outrageous lawsuit a number of years ago in which a woman spilled hot McDonald's coffee all over herself, sued the establishment, and won. But it get's better. Now obese people are taking McDonald's to court. Obese people aren't obese because of McDonald's. They are obese because they choose not to burn away the calories or because of their inescapable genetic makeup. In "Super Size Me," the great 2004 documentary by filmmaker Morgan Spurlock, we were educated on the theory that there is a point where corporate responsibility ends and personal responsibility begins. Corporate responsibility ends at the cash register, and personal responsiblity begins when you digest the food.

The same aspect applies to the gun industry, and in 2003, the endlessly fascinating "Runaway Jury," which was based on a novel by John Grisham, explored lawsuits against the gun industry. Although I disagreed with the outcome, I still gave the film four stars, but the bottom line is simple: companies aren't responsible for what their products do to people, especially by other people. A hopeless dote who blows his co-workers away can't be controled by the gun company that he purchased the firearm from. In the same way, a smoker should not be allowed to sue a tobacco company for hospital treatment for lung cancer. Any judge with a brain would dismiss the case immediately, give the plaintiff a middle finger, and wish him luck on his journey up the creek without a canoe or a paddle.

"Runaway Jury" and "Super Size Me" were answers to the ridiculous arguments against corporations. "Thank You For Smoking" is more of a hokey outcry rather than an answer. When Nick Taylor stands up for what he believes in, he is more than certain that he is right. He is just as determined as Uri Orlov from last year's excellent "Lord of War," who sold illegal arms to every army but the Salvation Army. Taylor is an orator, no more, no less. He is payed to talk, and tobacco companies world wide consider him a go-to man in their time of need.

"Thank You For Smoking" draws the curtain on American stupidity, revealing both sides of an argument that will never reach compromise. Taylor's job requires sometimes very dangerous work. He crosses paths with a number of characters in the media and political underworld, much like an assassin would in a gangster film. He is good friends with two very interesting people: Polly Bailey (Maria Bello), an alcoholic who is a lobyist for the alcohol industry, and Jay Bliss (David Koechner), a firearms industry spokesperson. Together, they call themselves The MOD (Merchants Of Death) Squad, meeting in a quiet restaurant for sandwiches and drinks on a regular basis, and discussing marketing their little club with t-shirts and bumper stickers.

Nick has a son named Joey, played by Cameron Bright, who we saw three weeks ago capping his father and being kidnapped by murderous pedophiles in "Running Scared." Here he is being homeschooled by his father, not just in academics, but in the tricks of his father's trade. Nick's boss is BR (J. K. Simmons), an aggressive hot-head who is determined to boost cigarette sales. Nick suggests the movies, in one of the film's most memorable sequences, so that tobacco can begin to appeal to all ages. He also suggests that all of the characters smoke, because, as he so cleverly observes, "these days when anybody smokes in the movies, they are either Europeans or psychopaths."

But wait, there's more. Nick even encounters Heather Holloway (Katie Holmes), a sexy journalist doing an investigaton for The Washington Probe. There is Jeff Megall (Rob Lowe), a corporate mongul who works as a vessel for Nick's ideas. There is Lorne Lutch (Sam Elliott), a former Marlboro Man who is dying of lung cancer and ready to speak out against the tobacco industry. There is also the Captain (Robert Duvall), a tobacco tycoon based in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, who sees Nick as a revolutionary for Amercian society. And then there is the matter of Senator Ortolan Finistirre (William H. Macy), who is quick to attack the tobacco industry from multiple directions but slow to realize that his homestate of Vermont, which produces cheddar cheese, is, in the context of his own arguement, a contributer to cholesterol, the leading cause of death in the United States, something that Nick is educated enough to point out by himself.

"Thank You For Smoking" would be the result if Quentin Tarantino were to attempt a social and politcal satire. Since Nick is such an intelligent professional, and because he is able to knock down his enemies one at a time, subtly pinpointing the stupidity of their own argument, the film is wide open for humorous, quotable dialogue that only continues to resonate once it penetrates your eardrums. On the part of writer/director Jason Reitman, no praise is too high. Like Paul Haggis did in devising "Crash," Reitman is able to juggle a number of very diverse characters and bring them to life with spirited animation. This is also one of the first satires I've seen in a while in which the humor is never of the goofy slapstick caliber, and seems to emerge so naturally from the material that you almost miss it once it emerges.

What makes the film so effective is that Nick is an obnoxious jerk that you can't help but adore. He is played with quiet enthusiasm by Aaron Eckhart, an actor who goes shamefully unmentioned when movie snobs gather together to discuss their obsession. He is so effective, with his smirk grin, uplifting voice, and sprawling confidence, that you actually accept him as a lobbyist. Nick belongs there. He has the look and behind-the-scenes personality as a confident professional who takes pleasure in doing his job. Even in handling the character of Nick, the film never goes into the conventional atmosphere of the genre. Unlike in "Lord of War," the hero never goes through a period in the third act in which he pays dearly for his sins. Nick makes out like a bandit.

Jason Reitman has directed a number of short films, but with his first full length project, he has struck gold and set up a mine. The only way to prevent myself from digging into the deeper layers of the film is to end my review. Checking out his resume on imdb.com would lead you to believe that he would never find a niche for himself in the world of filmmaking. Well, he has.

An excellent and biting political satire, this film is not so much about smoking as the PR-lobbyist industry - what they used to call, in more honest times, propaganda.  The US may not have a Dr. Goebbels and an official Ministry of Propaganda, but the technique of the Big Lie is alive and well in Washington.  (Although the modern PR industry was born in WW I America, when President Wilson commissioned Edward Bernays, nephew of Sigmund Freud, to sell American war involvement through the "Committee on Public Information."  Bernays was in fact connected to Big Tobacco also, promoting female smoking as "Torches of Freedom.")

In short, selling lies is the first step to profit and power.  Americans at least don't have the excuse as did other victims of propaganda: "we didn't know," and even if we did, there's police and prisons for saying differently.  Here it's even more insidious - the willful suspension of fact and common sense based on individual choice of what feels good and convenient.  Ironic but fitting that a country producing such a magnificent satire should be ruled by its current 45th president.

In the final cut, though, we have a film in which no one's really good or bad, and everyone wins in the end (except J. K. Simmons).  The deleted scene of Aaron Eckhart slapping the cigarette out of son Cameron Bright's mouth on the steps of Congress should have been retained to drive the last coffin nail, as cigarettes were once called.

The most interesting and successful thing about this movie is that it targets left-wing, liberal special-interest groups. Yes, right-wing conservative lobbyists get lots of criticism, too, but director Jason Reitman believes that the right-wing capitalists offer and preserve freedom of choice, the ultimate American value. In his view, Reitman believes that liberals are trying to brainwash us into following their views, which even when laudable are paternalistic and coercive.

The movie is refreshing, and Aaron Eckhart's breezy manner and handsome good looks are perfect in making a sleazy character very easy to like. The important relationship between Eckhart and his son is handled deftly and with as little sentiment as possible.

My only caveat with the movie is that it doesn't confront the damage to American society done by tobacco as directly as it should. I can't pull any statistics out of a hat, but your average heavy smoker dies a very messy and slow death. Many hospital wards are overpopulated even without smokers, and smokers just choke up hospital wait times even more. American courts realized that tobacco companies were not totally to blame, but they also realized the only entity that could afford to pay for increased medical costs was the tobacco industry with its deep pockets. Just raising taxes on society wouldn't come close to paying off the increase in medical and insurance bills.

So, even though writer/director Reitman is right to focus on freedom of choice, sometimes we have to admit limitations on our individual freedom when doing so is better for society at large--not just for others such as smokers, but the 3rd party innocents that suffer from tobacco use.
